Cobb County Fire & Emergency Services
September 8 at 11:26 AM ·

On Sunday, Batt. 3, T8, E21, and T21 participated in Lexy Trout's welcome home ceremony from her last chemo treatment. Lexy is 9 years old and was admitted into Scottish Rite Hospital on January 1st of this year with a severe headache. The test results came back as brain cancer, finding 3 tumors on her brain. After several surgeries, chemo therapy, and radiation over the past 9 months, Lexy is now cancer free. Lexy's parents wanted a big welcome home for her tonight after being discharged from her last chemo treatment so her friends, family, neighbors, and our Cobb Fire family showed up big for her. Lexy rang the bell on T21 to symbolize her last treatment. This kid has a huge heart and more courage than I can imagine. She won her battle with cancer with many additional hurdles to overcome due to Covid19. Congratulations Lexy!!! Thank you so much for inviting us, it was such an honor to be part of something so special.

Celebrate the centennial of women’s suffrage in the U.S. with Votes for Women: A Portrait of Persistence. Now on display at the Marietta Museum of History through 2020.

The story of women's suffrage is a story of voting rights, of inclusion in and exclusion from the franchise, and of our civic development as a nation. Votes for Women: A Portrait of Persistence, a poster exhibition from the Smithsonian, celebrates the 100th anniversary of the Nineteenth Amendment and explores the complexity of the women's suffrage movement and the relevance of this history to Americans' lives today.

The Marietta Museum of History is open Tuesday-Saturday, 11 a.m. until 4 p.m.(check website for holiday and COVID-19 related closings) Admission is $7 Adults, $5 Seniors and Students, 5 and under are free.

To learn more about the Marietta Museum of History, visit www.MariettaHistory.org.

post_text: This morning, Commissioner Bob Ott, District Attorney Joyette Holmes and Police Chief Tim Cox joined Representative Lucy McBath, Rabbi Sernovitz of Temple Kol Emeth and local religious leaders of all faiths to show their support for the Jewish community, who was targeted earlier this month when swastikas were spray-painted in an east Cobb neighborhood. “We are not a community of hate. We are a community of love and inclusiveness,” said Commissioner Ott. In a revitalized effort to bring the community together, Cobb County plans to revive the Community Relations Council and change its name and focus. Tentatively called the Council for Justice, Peace and Reconciliation, he says this new group will be the first step toward making things better.

For more information or to register, visit cobbcat.org/girlswhocode or call 770-801-5320.

Swift Justice supports Feed America

Years ago, Deputy Chief ADA Jesse Evans and other athlete-colleagues in the Cobb DA's Office formed the Swift Justice running team to support local charitable causes, engage in community activities outside our normal prosecution responsibilities, promote healthy habits, and build camaraderie. Last Friday, Swift Justice came together for Q-19 (quarantine/COVID 19) to benefit Feed America.

Enjoy a leisurely walking tour as you walk back in time and explore the property that has been farmed since 1840. The 135 acres that make up the original Hyde Farm consists of numerous cultural resources. Natural features include the Chattahoochee River, the forests that are found in both the lowlands adjacent to the river and the uplands near the home site. Man made features consist of the terraced agricultural fields, lowland pastures/old fields, the orchard, the home site, the meadows, and the farm outbuilding sites. Enjoy the pond that was built on Mulberry Creek in the 1980's, featuring geese, ducks, herons, turtles, beaver, and stocked with catfish and bass.

Two 45-minute tours are conducted the second Saturday of each month and begins at 10 a.m. and 11 a.m. Please call 770-528-8840 if you have any questions. Please register here: https://tinyurl.com/yynp4fcx

Yet another Cobb County leader has been selected for a prominent statewide position, as Cobb’s State Court Clerk leaves to become the first Clerk of the new statewide business court. Angie Davis was confirmed by the state House and Senate Judiciary committees Tuesday following her nomination by Governor Brian Kemp.
Davis leaves Cobb after more than 28 years of service. During her confirmation, Davis said her experience in Cobb prepared her well for this new challenge.
“The prospect of serving in a specialized court for the state of Georgia is so incredibly exciting,” Davis told the committee. “I’m driven by the idea of developing a first-in-class court. That’s the gold standard that my office currently operates under and has a reputation for pursuing.”
The new court begins operation next month. Robin Bishop, the Chief Deputy Clerk, will assume Davis’ role in Cobb County.

post_text: Juneteenth is the oldest nationally-celebrated commemoration of the ending of slavery in the United States. It has been referenced as America’s second Independence Day. Dating back to 1865, it was on June 19 that the Union soldiers, led by Major General Gordon Granger, landed at Galveston, Texas with news that the war had ended and that the enslaved were now free. Note that this was 2.5 years after Pres. Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation -- which had become official Jan. 1, 1863. The Emancipation Proclamation had little impact on Texas (and many places in the south) due to the minimal number of Union troops to enforce the Executive Order. However, with the surrender of General Lee in April of 1865, and the arrival of General Granger’s regiment, the forces were finally strong enough to influence and overcome the resistance.

Cobb Tax Commissioner Carla Jackson is reopening all offices today, June 8, with normal business hours of 8 a.m.-5 p.m., Monday-Friday. Under normal operations, the department processes approximately 40,000 in-person motor vehicle transactions each month. With that in mind, customers should expect wait times at maximum capacity in our tag offices.

To provide safe and exceptional customer service, the Tax Commissioner’s Office will use a program very similar to the technology used by many restaurants. The process takes three simple steps:

-Check-in by name and mobile number,
-Return to the vehicle to wait for text notification
-Upon notification, enter the office to receive service

Even with these procedures in place to protect the safety of staff and county residents, the safest options are to use e-services, tag kiosks, drop boxes and mail. For business requiring an in-person visit, office staff will follow recommendations of social distancing for safe interactions and use personal protective equipment. We are also encouraging visitors to wear a face mask for in-office visits.
